title: Keybinds do not appear to be working.
body: I'm on MacOSX 10.8.2 and the keybinds do not appear to be working correctly.  For example alt+d, alt+i simply produces an Ë† character (which is what I'd expect when typing alt+i if not mapped).  This is using a basic installation of Sublime Text 2.0.1 (Build 2217) and SublimeClang 2013.03.08.07.15.52 (GitHub).  I'm also not able to bring up the output panel which is probably pointing to the main issue, SublimeClang does show up in Preferences->Package Settings though.

title: Panel doesn't show all errors (C++)
Cannot install or use - OS X, ST2 build 2217
body:
Previously I used SublimeClang with absolutely no issues. As of about two weeks ago, it stopped working. After numerous uninstall and reinstall attempts, I still cannot get it working. 

Installing via Package Controller literally does nothing - it says it downloaded & installed it, but it does not even create the folder in the package directory.

Manually cloning the git repository also does not work. Although all the files seem to be there, it is evidently not loaded into Sublime Text and I get absolutely no feedback from it (no logs). The only evidence that it exists is the preference menu options. Changing these settings also has no effect.

At one point I deleted *all* of my Sublime Text 2 application support information, effectively removing any trace of it ever existing, then reinstalled it. The same issue with SublimeClang persisted.

title: Support simple ${project_path} syntax in options
body:
Simple ${project_path} can be convenient for per-project options like:

    "sublimeclang_options":
    [
      "-I${project_path}/../../../../build/texk",
      "-I${project_path}/../../../../build/texk/web2c",
      "-I${project_path}/../..",
      "-I${project_path}/.."
    ]

It's simpler to specify than more versatile ${project_path:filename} syntax.

title: Issue with cursor positioning after space
body:
Kwelity wrote in the [ST forums](http://www.sublimetext.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=3958&start=110#p44053)

```
Hi,

I have an issue with SublimeClang when using multiple cursors. Let me use an example :

Let say I have 4 functions

func1|
func2|
func3|
func4|

With for cursors at the end of the line.
if I hit space, the cursors will take a different position, shifting the positions to 1 character each line, like this 

func1 |
func |2
fun |c3
fu |nc4

I only have this issue when Clang is enable.

So if anyone have an idea ...

Thank you.
```

title: Tweak CMakeLists.txt to make it possible to build libclang 3.2 on Windows
Doesn't work with SSE includes
body:
In 64-bit Windows 7, a simple #include <ammintrin.h> fails with the following:

C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:118,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:118,20 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:119,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:119,21 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:120,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:120,20 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:121,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:121,21 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:122,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:122,23 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:123,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:123,24 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:124,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:124,23 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:125,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:125,24 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128d'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:126,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:126,20 - Error - use of undeclared identifier '__m128'
C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0/VC/include\ammintrin.h:127,1 - Error - unknown type name '__m128d'

The 3.2 clang headers have this file with the appropriate typedefs, but they go with a __builtin in clang, so just replacing the headers isn't working. A new build of libclang and libclang_x64 is probably required.

title: With a typedef pointer the completion shows on dot instead of on arrow
project settings being ignored on open project
complement std::unique_ptr<T>
body: When using std::unique_ptr<T> or std::shared_ptr<T> complement occurs when typing object. - get(), reset() and other methods in the classes. but when you typing object-> list additions is not displayed. should be a list of methods of a class T.

title: Make it work with Sublime Text 3
body: Need to make a couple of tweaks for the plugin to work with [Sublime Text 3](http://www.sublimetext.com/blog/articles/sublime-text-3-beta).

title: Configuring GCC 4.7.2 with sublime clang
body:
I used macports to install GCC 4.7.2. In the settings file, I changed the options to "-isystem", "/opt/local/**", because that is where all of the files are located; however, it gives me the message:

/path/to/directory/filename.h:5,10 - Fatal - 'array' file not found
Did you configure the include path used by clang properly?
See http://github.com/quarnster/SublimeClang for more details on how to configure SublimeClang.

whenever I include <array>. I am positive that the file is located in one of the directories in local.  I even changed it to "-I/opt/local/**", but that gave even more error messages, saying the files in the those directories use things not in the correct namespace, etc. Any way to correct this issue?

Edit: I searched my entire hard drive, the only two location where the file array is found are: /opt/local/include/gcc47/c++/array and /opt/local/include/gcc47/c++/tr1/array

Edit 2: I have included every possible folder in /opt/local/include. Now the plugin says there is a problem range_access.h and array. Also, it says there is no member named 'stoi' in namespace 'std' but the code compiles fine.

title: Issues with cross-compilation targets
body:
Context: Registered ST2 (2.0.1) on OS X 10.8.2

It seems that clang does not take target options for parsing:
 -triple
 -gcc-toolchain
 -target
options are ignored (a warning is emitted to report the option switches are ignored)

However, when editing source code that include target-specific files that contains low level definition and ASM instruction, clang fails with this typical kind of errors:

ns_util.h:333,11 - Error - unknown register name 'r1' in asm
nd_seqfs_fileio.c:173,1 - Error - argument to 'section' attribute is not valid for this target: mach-o section specifier requires a segment and section separated by a comma

My current target is arm-eabi, which explains the first error (r1 is an ARM register) and ELF is the target, not mach-o. It seems clang always try to parse with x86 / OS X in mind.

How to deal with cross-compilation targets?
Thanks.

title: static analyzer don't work.
SublimeClang crashes with this snippet
Crash sublime text2 then attempt show boost::variant autocomplete.
Autocompletion takes 700ms, editor hangs in the meanwhile.
body:
I'm starting my first really big project, and autocompletion is unusably slow. The editor freezes for 700ms before showing the completions and it's really annoying since I don't get immediate feedback on what I type anymore. So for instance, when I type "make_shared", it hangs after I typed m, and then when it can show autocompletions I'm already done typing make_shared.

Here are the settings I think matter and how I set them:

```JSON
{ // This is a snippet.
    "enabled": true,
    "automatic_completion_popup": true,
    "worker_threadcount": -1,
    "enable_fast_completions": true,
    "recompile_delay": 0,
    "index_parse_options": 13,
    "warm_up_in_separate_thread": true,
    "cache_on_load": true,
    "reparse_use_dirty_buffer": true, //True or false doesn't seem to matter for the hanging
    "time_completions": true, //shows e.g. Comp ~700ms Filt: ~20ms
    "inhibit_sublime_completions": true
}
```

Are there any settings I may have set wrong?

For reference: In my project I use SDL, Boost, Assimp, SOIL, Alure, my own engine, and Bullet. I know this is a lot of code to parse, but the annoying thing is the hanging of my editor, not that it takes a while (although that would be nice to see fixed as well, it's not what bothers me).

title: Intermittent hanging when triggering autocomplete
body:
I'm working on a C++ project in Sublime Text, and am encountering intermittent hangs for >=10s at a time when autocomplete is triggered (e.g. by typing '.', '::' and so on). Unfortunately it's not easy to reproduce the issue.

I realise this is very non-specific and probably not actionable. So... how would I go about trying to narrow down what's happening? I'm not hugely familiar with Python. Is there a way to get a Python stack trace when the issue occurs, like what you get with Instruments.app's Time Profiler for C/C++/Obj-C code?

title: Running libclang in a different process
body:
libclang occasionally crashes or hangs, bringing down with it Sublime Text 2.

How about spawning a child process and using it to call libclang? Then, when it crashes, a new one can be spawned without affecting the edit session. I suppose then the parent process and child process have to communicate using some IPC mechanism.

title: "Smart" goto
body:
Hi,

Love the plugin, it works far better than any other similar plugin I've used for Notepad++ etc. Really impressed.

One thing I'd like to see would be a smart goto kind of command which could take the place of both goto implementation and goto definition, because I find that I tend to have to stop a moment and think about what I need, and then remember which key combination is needed, and it'd be nice to just have the one magic button to hit.

I'm thinking it would work like this:

```
if can find implementation:
    if cursor already at implementation:
        goto definition.
    else:
        goto implementation.
else:
    goto definition.
```

So basically it'll try and go to the implementation by default, but go to the definition instead if it can't find the implementation. Additionally if the user is already at the line with the implementation, it'll swap to the definition, and visa-versa.

Even if this command isn't key-bound by default, but is available as an alternative that people can configure themselves. That would be really great, and wouldn't affect what people are currently used to.

Cheers,
Frank.

title: Cached data not removed from the memory on closing window
body:
I have one pretty big project using SublimeClang. If I open it, memory usage raises significantly (having "cache_on_load": true and a lot of files open 'helps' with that). If I then switch to some other project that doesn't use SublimeClang, memory usage does not go down. Same thing when having two ST windows open and closing the one with a big project that was using SublimeClang.

This is maybe because ST2 doesn't provide hooks for knowing whether data is "unused" but maybe it can be detected somehow?

title: Smart and comprehensive highlighting
body: C++ code highlighting support has generally been lackluster in IDEs. Implementing something like KDevelop 4's semantic highlighting, but actually almost always correct would be a great boon.
